content.description:
Climb the slabby shallow white corner to the top. The corner is slick and some interesting stemming possibilities can be used.

On the Burgers & Fries descent ramp.
2 bolts, no gear.

Start off ledge next to Over 60 With Asian Assistance.

Go up the short crack.



Burgers and fries left.

Single rack

Climb the arch to the left Burgers & Fries and continue up the slab above.

Burgers & Fries Main Wall
Bolts & small gear

Starts with awesome gear and is clean. It is pretty awesome climbing with a sort of awkward move to get off the ledge about 2/3 of the way up, and its well protected. The Squamish Guide book says this route is 5.8 and I thought it was a little soft even for that rating. Regardless, it was really fun. South of the Main Wall of Burgers and Fries. Head up a small side trail through the trees, and go right at the wall. You will come to a left-facing groove/dihedral. This groove is the start for Gollum/Sour Grapes (5.7). Just to the left is the start for Bilbo Baggins. Around the corner to the right is Frodo's First Step. Gear to 3 inches, rap rings at top

climbs.name: Burgers and Fries
climbs.fa: John Manuel, Ed Spat, Brian DeHertog, 1980

content.description:
Toward the left side of the wall is a crack that goes up and ends below what appears to be a blank face.  There is actually a horizontal crack above, that is invisible from the ground. 
  
 Above this horizontal crack, there isn't any more pro, and there are still a few slabby moves ahead.

Standard rack.  Two bolts at the top.  No rappel anchor.  Walk off left.

A mix of face climbing down low, connecting with cracks and corner features up top. Fun route that climbs quickly. Located just right of Wise Crack, and left of Catch Me Quick.

Rappel route with a single 50m rope, but, mind your rope ends. Two bolts protect the start, then a mix of gear to the top.

Start up a finger crack that leads to the crux, and the only 10b part, 7m off the deck. The rest of the climb is more of a 5.9 with various finishes, the mantle finish is more exciting.

Smoke Bluffs - Burgers and Fries
You can protect the crux with a orange Metollius cam, or a DMM walnut.

Catch You shares it's start with Move It On Over.  Fairly easy moves to the first bolt lead to thin, sequency friction climbing before you gain a flaring finger crack.  The climbing eases in difficulty from here and varies between flaring cracks and face climbing.

At Burgers & Fries, just left of Move It On Over.
Bolts and thin trad gear.  Small offset pro may be helpful.  Anchor is bolted and a 60m rope is long enough to TR.

Deep broken cracks.

The groove right of Jammer's Delight.
1 set of nuts, Cams from 06-3.5 . Bolted anchor at top with rap rings.

Left-leaning crack system.  Route starts above stacked flakes at the base of the wall.  Trends left.  Fun route with good protection.

Left of Wisecrack. Starts above stacked flakes at the base of the wall.
Single rack to 2". Bolted anchor. Walk off.

Climb the blocky corner up to a vegetated ledge and finish left or right.



The big blocky groove to the left of Split Personality.

Single rack.

Step up blocky granite steps.  Climb a hand crack to a ramp.  Follow ramp left to anchors.

13 feet right of Split Personality.
SR. 2-bolt anchors with rappel at the top. So you can rappel off or walk off.

Climb the easy crack until it ends, here head up a thin L-shaped crack on the low angled rock.

Located on the descent ramp from the top of Burger & Fries.
Standard Rack

Crux for me was getting to the first bolt.  Pick your evil - go up left with technical balancy moves or right with bouldery moves.  I like the left. The slab climbing above has good edges, perhaps more so than the 10a beside because it doesn't get climbed nearly as much.

To the right of High Boltage Line.
3 bolts, bring small cams for the top (book says to 1.5"). Bolted anchor.

This short crack is a good intro climb for new leaders. This may be a better way to get to the hand crack on Gollum. South of the Main Wall of Burgers and Fries. Head up a small side trail through the trees, and go right at the wall. You will come to a left-facing groove/dihedral. This groove is the start for Gollum/Sour Grapes (5.7). Just to the left is the start for Bilbo Baggins. Around the corner to the right is Frodo's First Step. Small rack to 2 inches. Two bolts at the top, though I recommend a directional if you are going to top-rope the route (to keep the rope out of the crack). You can walk off right (with a spotter at the bottom), or rappel off of trees.

Follow a large ramp up to a bolt. Clip this bolt and delicately move across into a left leaning finger crack. This is the hardest crux of the route and the climbing is easier above. This crack ends and there is one more easier crux getting onto the slab above. The rest of this route is pure slab climbing and is very similar to the top of the neighboring route Peaches and Cream. 
  
 Climbing straight up to the first bolt ups the grade on the route. Staying high on the ramp and traversing over to the first bolt is probably what the was original intended at the 5.11a grade. 
  
 Bring some gear to protect the cracks.

Main Burgers & Fries wall between Peaches and Cream and Dusty Eyes.
3 bolts, Standard Rack

This is a great 5.7 hand crack. Start up the deep dihedral to to an obvious hand crack just past the wide ledge on the right (~2/3rds up). South of the Main Wall of Burgers and Fries. Head up a small side trail through the trees, and go right at the wall. You will come to a left-facing groove/dihedral. The dihedral is the start for Gollum. The groove to the left is the start for Bilbo Baggins (5.9, another great hand-crack). Standard Rack to 3 inches. Belay off trees, or (with a directional) off the two bolts to the right (above Bilbo Baggins).

Right of an obvious, brushy gully to the right of Predator lies a nice, fully bolted line. High Boltage Line scampers up initially easy ground to the first bolt above a bulge, then tiptoes up steep, thin ground to the top. Precise footwork required.


Bolts.  Anchor from trees to belay from the top.  Walk off.

A nice finger crack.  This climb isn't a total bomb, but it is quite short, and it is too easy to step off the crack to ledges at the top.  The fingers in the middle of the climb are good though, and it protects well on nuts.

This route is in the trees to the right of the Burgers and Fries Main Wall.  There is a trail up into it.  Head left when you get to the wall.  The crack is just to the left of a groove and shallow right-facing dihedral.

Nuts and cams to 2 inches. Rap rings at top.

From the descent ramp, climb up the initial thin slab and mantle up and onto a slight ledge. From there follow the remaining two bolts up the hard slab/face to the top. The crux is just above the last bolt.

Located on the descent ramp from the top of Burger & Fries.
3 bolts, no gear.

A great 5.7 hand crack.  The start is tough, especially when wet.  I used a belayer's shoulder.  One could also A0 through the first 5 feet.

Take the Valley Trail south from the Burgers and Fries Main wall until you come to a residence, the carapace of an old pick-up truck, and stairs down.  This route is to your left, the stairs down lead to Alexis Cracks, the residence is a good reason to stay quiet, and I can't comment on the truck.
Mostly large nuts and cams to 3 inches.  Bolted anchor at the top.

This short route climbs the thin slab past two bolts.

Located on the descent ramp from the top of Burger & Fries.
2 bolts, no gear.

At the right end of the Main Wall are parallel cracks that don't quite make it to the ground.  This is Movin' on Over.  Fingers to hands. 
  
 There are bolts on both the left and right of the route (on other routes).  Either one can be used to protect the opening moves into the crack, if you are so inclined (though I'm pretty sure both were added much much later than the FA).  The crux is getting established into the crack.   
  
 At the top, there is a right-facing dihedral.  You can go right or left here.  The left is better.

At the right-hand side of the Main Wall.
Gear to 2 inches.  Two-bolt anchor.  Walk off left.

Climb the bolted line up slab just to the left of Jammers Delight.

Approach as for Burgers and Fries, follow base of the crag far right past Sweet and Sour around the corner and look to the left side of the next cliff.

3 bolts with some gear

Climb up the streak on the virgin slab directly between between High Boltage and French Leave. Better climbing than both of these routes as the slab hasn't been polished. Stay off the crack system of French Leave and climb it as a pure slab route all the way to the top.

This route is top rope only so climb either High Boltage and French Leave first, either set of anchors can be used for a top rope anchor.

Burgers & Fries right.
Top rope only, use High Boltage or French Leave anchors

This is an interesting route that requires a tough pull to get off the ground. After making crux moves to get going, make another hard move to step right to an easier groove, move more easily up to another crux (layback), and finish up on easier cracks. The protection is plentiful and easy to place from good stances. 
  
 (The route name and first ascent information were obtained from "Squamish Select" by Marc Bourdon.)

This route is about ten feet right of Libya Sucks and right before a fence demarcating private property. Look for an off-fingers crack at the start with poor feet.
Standard rack. I used medium nuts and cams from a blue Alien to #3 Camalot. There is a bolted rappel anchor at the top.

climbs.name: Over 60 with Asian Assistance
climbs.fa: David Hutchinson, Joe Wong, Eric Chan, 2015

content.description:
Interesting slab, micro features lead to some thoughtful footwork. A tad run out to the anchor.



Left of Asshole of November


7 Bolts

Climb up the hard slab with only a few bolts for protection. The "mental" crux of this route is going between the second and third bolt. The route gets easier here but is substantially run out.  
  
 Most choose to top rope this route as it is a bold lead.

On the main Burgers & Fries wall, the obvious slab between Catch Me Quicker and Catch You.
3 bolts, also some possible protection near the top.

A straight up, slabby climb. On the lower angle sections your handholds are little pebbles. You will learn to love these pebbles.

As you approach the Burgers and Fries wall from the left, this is the third climb. A straight up, slabby climb.

3 Bolts + small gear

Climb a good hand crack until it fades out near the top. At this point transfer into another great left leaning crack that continues to the top.

Near the descent ramp for Burgers & Fries.
Standard Rack

Climb the desperately thin slab that is immediately to the left of Burgers & Fries. The difficulty eases as you get higher.

Burgers & Fries Main Wall
4 bolts

Right of Smeagol, climb the face to reach a left leaning hand crack.


SR

The right most route on the large slab. This route is a bit vague as to when you should start using the crack on the right.

Burgers and Fries Right
1 bolt, small gear

Cracks so deep you almost fit in. A great novice climb.

In the Squamish Select as "Sarah's Crack".

Standard rack.

Crack to the left of Jims Jam. Guide gives it 5.9, but it's worth doing if you can't climb that grade since it's easy to cheat to the right

Follow the path to the right of Burgers and Fries right half, down some stone stairs and you will quickly find it.
Standard rack

climbs.name: Short and Sweet
climbs.fa: Bob Wilson, Terry Spurrel, Barry Wiseman  1980

content.description:
The short crack about three meters to the right of Swan Song. Follow it up and left to finish on Swan Song.

the right side of burgers and fries left.
Standard rack

I found the crux to be at the bottom, an awkward move or two that is harder than it looks.

The right-most crack on this small wall.  You can walk off to the right.
SR - I don't remember there being an anchor at the top, but there is a tree.

Start up a short piece of slab to reach a curved finger crack.  After the break in the crack is a well protected water polished re entry to the end of the finger crack.

13 ft left approx. of Exit Stage Left
Sr

Climb the bolted slab between Split Personality and Exit Stage Left. The slab is steep and smooth with several well needed defined edges and pockets.

Burgers and Fries Right.
3 bolts, standard rack

Climb the tricky slab past four bolts into the top crack system. A small lonely crack can be used for protection between the first and second bolts. Crux of the route is at the last bolt where it gets very thin. 
  
 This route protects nicely and is not run out like it's neighboring hard slab route Over Forty.

Main Burgers & Fries wall between Move it On Over and Short and Sweet.
4 bolts, standard rack.

climbs.name: Sweet and Sour
climbs.fa: Kris Wild, Fern Webb, Robin Beech  2003

content.description:
Follow up the cack just right of Short and Sweet up to a bolt and a small ledge. Proceed right up the corner to another bolt and then up slab to the anchor.

Far right of Burgers and Fries left.
2 bolts, 1 set of nuts, standard rack.

Climb a line of 4 bolts up the slab. At the second bolt there is a bulge, stay to the right of the remaining bolts. As the route steepens there are several useful edges. 
  
 The crux is at the third bolt. Don't be tempted by the big crack on the left (False Friends route) when getting to the first bolt.

Located on the descent ramp from the top of Burger & Fries.
4 bolts, no gear.

climbs.name: Three Cool Kats
climbs.fa: E Chan, T Sanwald, A Douglas (2015)

content.description:
Climb a cool short hand crack to the top. A great lead for beginners.

Near the descent ramp for Burgers & Fries.
Standard Rack

Leads up a wonderful corner crack with a fun bulge about halfway (don't side pull folks /s) There is a bolted mid-station for multi-pitch practice.

far far right burgers and fries, to the left of Libya Sucks
1 set of nuts and cams from 0.6-3.5"

If someone knows anything about this route, please add info. It's not in the guidebook, but it's clean and seems to get traffic. Start up a discontinuous crack just left of Libya sucks (look for the hole where you can thread a nut). The crux comes about halfway up where the crack ends, requiring either a big reach up or shenanigans in a seam to the left. Cross a slab yo the right and finish on Libya Sucks.
  • At the little crag through the trees 20m past Burgers and Fries right. Center of the wall, to the left of the nice hand crack.
Single rack from small fingers through hands. I like to thread a big nut for the first piece, and I think a green camalot protected the crux.

Use good edges and a finger crack to climb the relatively steep first half. Walk across a ledge past an optional midway anchor (or use it for multi-pitch practice) and finish up the short but fun hand crack in the left facing corner to the actual anchor. Good movement and great pro, perhaps soft for the grade. 



Just left of Truck Stop Jamb. Follow the Burgers and Fries trail until you reach the last section of the cliff before the private fence cuts you off. White Line Fever is the leftmost of these cracks. 

Standard rack. Takes everything fingers to hands, no doubles needed. Bolted anchors with chains.

The left most route on the large slab. There is no gear until high up so most people top-rope this route. Bottom is starting to get polished from heavy use.

Burgers and Fries Right
No bolts, small gear high up

On the open slab to the left of Split Personality there is a thin diagonal crack that disappears into the slab. Climb this crack until you can clip a bolt, then smear your way up the remaining short section of slab.

Burgers and Fries Right
1 bolt, standard rack

Thin face climbing up to a short shallow crack up high.  Crux is right off the deck.

Right side of the crag.  Between Who Needs Bolts and Predator.
The crack will take small cams but it is high up.  No bolts.

climbs.name: Wisecrack
climbs.fa: B. Wiseman, B. Wilson, T. Spurrell 1980

content.description:
Wisecrack is one of two popular 5.7s at Burger and Fries.  Begin left of Carch Me, and right of the gentle ramp, Dusty Eyes. 
  
 Climb some left angling cracks to a small tree stump halfway up the face.  Move right to a flake, and layback unttil making a few easier moves to the top.     
  
 The initial moves into the flake are disconcerting and the gear is small.

Gear to 2".  #3 microcams protect the inital moves onto the flake.

Burgers and Fries is among the most popular areas as Smoke Bluffs, with easy top rope access, a selection of moderate lines, and a quick-drying western aspect that gets lots of sun.  This area can be a zoo, but there are some nice climbs here, particularly easy ones. 
  
 There is a whole slew of houses crazy close to the top of the crag.  To prevent issues with the homeowners, don't loiter at the top.
